Evidency: We design the Auditory Code Overview and Navigation Tool (ACONT) as an attempt to support the task of a programmer quickly scrolling through a class file in order for them to gain a quick understanding of its structure

In this paper, we adapt the virtual cursor model to enable code skimming. We add heading tags to class and function declarations as well as control flow statements such as if statements and for loops. This allows a blind programmer to quickly cycle through the heading tags at a particular level and for example move through all the functions inside a class. Blind users already use this strategy to quickly navigate to important sections of webpages [9]. We also present an eclipse plugin that allows a programmer to read the currently open file in the virtual cursor.

In this section, we first describe the five Issue Categories in detail as they are found in the traditional literature sources, blogs, email lists, as well as workshop observation. 
From our findings, we are able to summarize web development accessibility issues into the following five categories: visual information without an accessible equivalent, orienting, navigating, lack of support, and use of supportive technology.

We identified and grouped specific programming activities and tasks that have been reported to be challenging to people with visual impairments as well as the interventions that have been proposed to address these challenges. We believe a new review and analysis of the status quo is needed given the recent increase in research activities in this domain
